questions.text: Cells NOT involved in the immune response in the skin:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Melanocytes. Melanocytes are not primarily involved in the immune response in the skin. These cells are specialized for the production of melanin, the pigment responsible for skin color and protection against UV radiation. While melanocytes play a role in protecting skin cells from UV-induced damage, they do not participate directly in the immune defense or inflammatory responses. Their primary function is pigment production, making them unrelated to the immune response in the skin. A. Langerhans cells are involved in the immune response in the skin. They are a type of dendritic cell found in the epidermis, and they play a critical role in detecting foreign pathogens and initiating immune responses. Langerhans cells act as antigen-presenting cells, alerting the immune system to potential threats. B. Keratinocytes are the predominant cell type in the epidermis and are involved in the immune response through the release of cytokines and other signaling molecules. While their primary role is the formation of the skin barrier, they also have immune functions, including responding to injury and infection by activating inflammatory pathways. C. Dendritic cells are key players in the skin’s immune system. Similar to Langerhans cells, dendritic cells are antigen-presenting cells that capture and present antigens to T cells, triggering adaptive immune responses. These cells are crucial for detecting and responding to pathogens and other harmful stimuli.

questions.text: All are causes of primary acantholysis except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) CMV (Cytomegalovirus). CMV is not a cause of primary acantholysis. Acantholysis refers to the loss of cell-to-cell adhesion in the epidermis, leading to the formation of blisters. CMV, a viral infection, does not typically cause primary acantholysis. While it can cause various skin manifestations, it is not directly associated with the disruption of keratinocyte adhesion, which is characteristic of acantholysis. B. Darier’s disease is a genetic disorder that causes primary acantholysis. It is characterized by mutations in the ATP2A2 gene, leading to defects in calcium regulation within the skin cells. This results in the separation of epidermal cells (acantholysis) and the formation of blisters and skin lesions. C. Hailey Hailey disease is another genetic disorder that causes primary acantholysis. This condition is due to mutations in the ATP2C1 gene, affecting the functioning of the Golgi apparatus in keratinocytes, which leads to skin cell separation and acantholysis. Hailey Hailey disease often results in recurrent skin erosions and blisters. D. Pemphigus is an autoimmune disorder that causes primary acantholysis. In pemphigus, autoantibodies target desmogleins, which are proteins involved in cell adhesion in the skin. This results in the loss of adhesion between keratinocytes and the formation of blisters, which is characteristic of acantholysis in pemphigus.

Correct Answer (C) 1:36. The epidermal-melanin unit refers to the functional relationship between the melanocytes and the surrounding keratinocytes in the epidermis. In a typical unit, one melanocyte provides melanin to approximately 36 keratinocytes. This ratio is important for skin pigmentation and protection from UV damage. The number 1:36 is a commonly accepted ratio in human skin, where melanocytes distribute their melanin pigment to nearby keratinocytes, allowing the skin to achieve its pigmentation and protective properties. A. 1:20 is incorrect because this ratio is too low compared to the actual ratio observed in human skin. While there may be some variability in different individuals and skin types, the typical number of keratinocytes per melanocyte is much higher than 20. B. 1:30 is also incorrect, although it's closer to the correct ratio, the standard ratio is considered to be 1:36, making this slightly less accurate. D. 1:10 is incorrect because this ratio would suggest that melanocytes are in much higher density than they actually are in the epidermis. The 1:10 ratio is not typical for the distribution of melanocytes and keratinocytes in human skin.

questions.text: A 19-year old male presents with several comedones, papules and pustules on face and trunk. The appropriate drug of choice for the patient would be
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Topical retinoic acid + Oral doxycycline. In this case, the patient presents with several comedones, papules, and pustules on the face and trunk, which are characteristic of moderate to severe acne vulgaris. The appropriate treatment for moderate to severe acne typically involves both topical and oral therapy. Topical retinoic acid is used to promote cell turnover and prevent clogged pores, while oral doxycycline, a tetracycline antibiotic, helps reduce inflammation and bacterial overgrowth (specifically Propionibacterium acnes), which is often a contributing factor in acne. Combining these two treatments is effective in managing moderate to severe acne. A. Topical retinoic acid alone is not sufficient for moderate to severe acne, as it primarily addresses comedones but does not sufficiently control the inflammatory component of the disease. While effective for mild acne, topical retinoic acid alone may not provide enough improvement for this patient’s condition, which also includes papules and pustules. C. Topical clindamycin is an antibiotic that is used to reduce P. acnes on the skin. It is often effective for mild to moderate acne, but it does not address the underlying causes of acne, such as clogged pores and abnormal keratinocyte shedding, as well as oral doxycycline does. Therefore, for moderate to severe acne, it is typically used in combination with other treatments, rather than alone. D. Topical azithromycin is not commonly used in acne treatment. While azithromycin has antibacterial properties, it is not considered first-line therapy for acne. The more established treatments, such as topical retinoids and oral antibiotics like doxycycline, have been proven to be more effective in managing moderate to severe acne.

choices.text: Result of chronic rubbing and scratching
Associated with acute exacerbations of eczemas

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Result of chronic rubbing and scratching. Lichenification refers to the thickening and accentuation of skin markings, often resulting from chronic rubbing, scratching, or irritation. It typically occurs in conditions like eczema or atopic dermatitis, where patients may repeatedly scratch the affected areas, leading to this characteristic thickening of the skin. This process is a response to repeated trauma or inflammation, and it is seen in long-standing or chronic skin conditions. A. Seen in irritant dermatitis is incorrect because irritant dermatitis, while it can lead to skin inflammation, does not typically result in lichenification unless the irritation becomes chronic and repetitive. Lichenification is more specifically associated with conditions involving repeated scratching or rubbing, such as atopic dermatitis. C. Associated with acute exacerbations of eczemas is incorrect because lichenification is a feature of chronic eczema, not acute exacerbations. Acute eczema typically presents with erythema, vesicles, and weeping, whereas lichenification develops over time due to persistent irritation. D. Histologically shows spongiosis is incorrect because spongiosis, which is the intercellular edema seen in acute eczema, is not the hallmark of lichenification. Lichenification involves epidermal thickening and hyperkeratosis, which are different histologic features from spongiosis, which is more indicative of acute inflammatory skin conditions.

choices.text: Sandwitched between stratum spinosum & stratum granulosum
Also called as prickle cell layer

questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Contain degenerated cells. The stratum lucidum is a thin, translucent layer of the epidermis, typically found in thick skin, such as the palms of the hands and soles of the feet. This layer consists of flattened, dead, and degenerated keratinocytes that have lost their nuclei and organelles. These cells are in the process of transitioning into fully keratinized cells as they move towards the outer layers of the skin, contributing to the skin's protective barrier. A. Sandwiched between stratum spinosum & stratum granulosum is incorrect because the stratum lucidum lies between the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum, not between the stratum spinosum and stratum granulosum. The stratum spinosum is located below the stratum granulosum, while the stratum lucidum is more superficial. B. Contains hair bulbs is incorrect because hair bulbs are not found in the stratum lucidum. Hair bulbs are located in the dermis, where hair follicles originate. The stratum lucidum is part of the epidermis and does not contain structures like hair bulbs. C. Also called as prickle cell layer is incorrect because the "prickle cell layer" refers to the stratum spinosum, not the stratum lucidum. The stratum spinosum is named for the spiny appearance of its cells due to the presence of desmosomes, which are not present in the stratum lucidum.

choices.text: Melanocytes are the most prevalent epidermal cell
Keratin filaments are a hall mark of epidermal cells

questions.text: All statements are true regarding skin except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Melanocytes are the most prevalent epidermal cell. This statement is incorrect because keratinocytes are the most prevalent cells in the epidermis, not melanocytes. Keratinocytes make up about 90% of the cells in the epidermis and are responsible for producing keratin, which forms a protective barrier for the skin. Melanocytes, which produce melanin and contribute to skin pigmentation, are far less numerous in comparison, making up only about 5-10% of the epidermal cells. A. Skin is stratified squamous epithelium is correct. The skin is composed of stratified squamous epithelium, which means it consists of several layers of flattened cells. This type of epithelium helps provide protection against mechanical stress, dehydration, and pathogens. C. Keratin filaments are a hallmark of epidermal cells is correct. Keratin filaments, which are part of the cytoskeleton of keratinocytes, are essential for maintaining the structural integrity of the epidermis. These filaments form a strong network that helps the skin resist mechanical stress. D. Filaggrin assists in keratinization is correct. Filaggrin is a protein that plays a crucial role in the process of keratinization, which is the process by which keratinocytes undergo transformation into dead, flattened cells that form the outermost protective layer of the skin. Filaggrin binds to keratin filaments, aiding in their aggregation and contributing to the formation of the skin barrier.

questions.text: Acantholysis is due to destruction of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Intercellular adhesion. Acantholysis refers to the loss of adhesion between keratinocytes, which is the cause of blister formation in various skin conditions. The process of acantholysis occurs when the intercellular adhesion molecules, particularly desmosomes, are disrupted. Desmosomes are responsible for holding adjacent skin cells (keratinocytes) together. When these adhesion molecules are damaged or dysfunctional, the cells can separate, leading to the formation of fluid-filled spaces or blisters within the epidermis. A. Filaggrin is incorrect because filaggrin is a protein involved in the formation of the skin's barrier function and in the keratinization process. It does not play a direct role in the cell-cell adhesion that causes acantholysis. Filaggrin mutations are associated with conditions like atopic dermatitis, but not with acantholysis. B. Intercellular cement is incorrect because while intercellular cement (mainly composed of lipids) contributes to the skin's barrier function, it is not the primary structure responsible for the adhesion between keratinocytes. The loss of adhesion that causes acantholysis is primarily due to the disruption of desmosomal proteins, not the intercellular cement. C. Basement membrane is incorrect because the basement membrane is a structure that separates the epidermis from the dermis. Acantholysis involves the separation of epidermal cells (keratinocytes) within the epidermis, not the detachment of the epidermis from the underlying dermis. Damage to the basement membrane can lead to other conditions, such as epidermolysis bullosa, but it is not the cause of acantholysis.

Correct Answer (C) Keratinocytes and keratinocytes. Desmosomes are specialized cell structures that help provide mechanical strength by connecting keratinocytes to each other. They consist of transmembrane proteins (desmogleins and desmocollins) that link the cytoskeletons of adjacent keratinocytes, helping to maintain the integrity of the epidermis. This intercellular adhesion is crucial for skin function, as it prevents the epidermal cells from separating under physical stress. A. Keratinocytes and melanocytes is incorrect because melanocytes, which produce melanin, are connected to keratinocytes by a different type of cell junction, mainly hemidesmosomes and melanosome transfer mechanisms, rather than desmosomes. Desmosomes specifically link keratinocytes to one another. B. Melanocytes and Merkel cells is incorrect because melanocytes and Merkel cells are different types of cells in the skin, and they are not connected by desmosomes. Merkel cells, involved in sensation, and melanocytes are found in the epidermis but serve different functions and are not directly linked by desmosomes. D. Langerhans cells and keratinocytes is incorrect because Langerhans cells, which are involved in immune surveillance, are not connected to keratinocytes by desmosomes. Instead, they have their own specialized functions within the epidermis, and while they interact with keratinocytes, this interaction does not primarily rely on desmosomal connections.

Correct Answer (A) Keratinocyte. A Tzanck cell is a type of epithelial cell, specifically a keratinocyte, which is seen in certain skin conditions like herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections, pemphigus vulgaris, and other blistering diseases. These cells are characterized by their large, multinucleated appearance due to the viral infection or acantholysis (separation of epidermal cells). The presence of Tzanck cells can be identified through a Tzanck smear, which helps in diagnosing these conditions. B. Fibroblast is incorrect. Fibroblasts are connective tissue cells involved in the production of collagen and extracellular matrix. They do not typically appear in a Tzanck smear, as they are not part of the epidermal layer of the skin and are not associated with conditions like herpes or pemphigus vulgaris, where Tzanck cells are commonly found. C. Neutrophil is also incorrect. Neutrophils are a type of white blood cell involved in the body's immune response to infection. They can be found in inflammatory responses but are not the cell type described as a Tzanck cell. Tzanck cells are specifically epithelial cells, not immune cells. D. Lymphocyte is incorrect as well. Lymphocytes are another type of white blood cell, involved in immune functions such as fighting viral infections. While they play a role in conditions involving Tzanck cells, they are not the cells seen in a Tzanck smear.

choices.text: Cell with hyperchromatic nuclei and perinuclear halo
Cell with hypochromatic nuclei and perinuclear halo

questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cell with hyperchromatic nuclei and perinuclear halo. In pemphigus, acantholytic cells are typically characterized by having hyperchromatic nuclei (darker staining due to increased DNA content) and a perinuclear halo, which appears as a clear area around the nucleus. This feature occurs due to acantholysis, which is the loss of cell-to-cell adhesion in the epidermis, often caused by autoantibodies targeting desmosomal proteins. The result is that the epidermal cells detach and appear as individual cells with these distinctive features on histological examination. B. Cell with hypochromatic nuclei and perinuclear halo is incorrect. Hypochromatic nuclei (lighter staining nuclei) are not typically seen in acantholytic cells. In pemphigus, the nuclei of the acantholytic cells are hyperchromatic rather than hypochromatic due to the nature of the cell's chromatin. C. Multinucleated cells is incorrect. While multinucleated cells can be seen in certain conditions, acantholytic cells in pemphigus are typically mononucleated. The characteristic of these cells is more related to their hyperchromatic nuclei and perinuclear halo rather than being multinucleated. D. None of the above is incorrect because option A correctly describes the characteristic appearance of acantholytic cells in pemphigus, making this answer not applicable.

questions.text: Identify the following lines in dermatology:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)Langer lineLanger’s lines, also called cleavage lines or skin tension lines, are natural orientation patterns of collagen fibers within the dermis. These lines represent the direction in which the skin has the least flexibility and the greatest tension. They were first described by Karl Langer in the 19th century, who studied how skin incisions spread when punctured with a circular tool. Langer’s lines usually run transversely in the limbs, horizontally around the trunk, and follow the natural wrinkles and folds of the skin. Clinically, they are very important in surgery because incisions made parallel to Langer’s lines tend to heal faster, with less scarring and better cosmetic results, whereas incisions made across them may gape open and leave more visible scars. These lines are not visible on normal skin but can be identified using tension tests or by observing natural skin folds. They differ from Blaschko’s lines, which follow embryonic cell migration, and from dermatomes, which follow nerve supply. Thus, Langer’s lines are identified by their regular, elliptical, and tension-related orientation, unlike the wavy, V-shaped, or S-shaped patterns of Blaschko’s lines.

questions.text: Apocrine sweat glands are present on which part of the body?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Option A,B,D-Eccrine sweat glands occur over most of the body like scalp,pam and soles,face etc. and open directly onto the skin's surface. Option C-Apocrine glands open into the hair follicle, leading to the surface of the skin. Apocrine glands develop in areas with many hair follicles, such as on the armpits and groin.
